pros: Awesome management and great benefits.
cons: Since it is a nonprofit, the salary is not the same as for-profit sector.

pros: great pay great environment great people
cons: bad timing bad hr no communication

pros: Overall AAAS, was an okay employer and that's really b/c they were a step up from my last god-awful employer.
cons: A glorified job placement office for newly minted PhD trying to secure a Fed position (and avoiding the dead-end regular way of applying.) STPF is full of incompetent/ phoned-it-in employees with only 2 (maybe 3) staff actually doing the work to keep the place going. The rest landed a cushy position that requires barely any effort (yet, still sometimes manage to screw up simple tasks). The toxic work culture and zero accountability for egregious behavior by "directors" means that good hires don't last very long. The communication dept in particular is a joke but protected by their minority status in several categories. So many official complaints on file with HR but AAAS will never do anything about it. If you go with the status quo; ignore obvious mismanagement; drink the "we promote science!" (but really don't) kool-aid; have little interest in career growth; and keep up the pretense of working, then you will do just fine here!

pros: good company good environment good people
cons: not found any yet for now

pros: - Great work-life balance - Trusted to do your work independently
cons: - No opportunities for growth - Minimum salary for the DC area

pros: Incredible benefits package with retirement matching at a level that's almost unheard of.
cons: Difficult to move up within the organization. Lots of groups have very flat management structures that make advancement difficult.

pros: Overall friendly environment and supportive
cons: difficult to reach management also

pros: good business environment of work
cons: salary is not so good

pros: Very flexible depending on what department you're in. They really care about keeping you.
cons: Lots of secrets - hush hush culture.

pros: networking and the opportunity to transition from science to science policy
cons: Not a permanent position and a long application process .

review_title: Mission-driven, but low salary and no upward mobility
pros: Interesting work. Retirement package (Match program) is generous.
cons: Low salary, position expectation is to perform numerous roles, no promotional tracks.

review_title: Interesting mission, but little regard for lower level employees
pros:
Decent work life balance, rarely worked above 40 hours a week and that was optional.

Part of an organization that publishes fascinating research.

Everyone I work with and speak to at AAAS is polite.
cons:
Organization won't commit to a proper cost of living adjustment that would at least guarantee myself being paid the same wage that I started with, instead of less than that.

No clear path to career advancement.

Currently at an all time high of employee turnover, many in senior positions.

Higher level management claims to want input on processes but never implements it.

In the many years that I have worked here, no attempt has been made to organize a lunch or happy hour event for anyone I work with, including in the years pre-pandemic, despite senior management expressing appreciation for our department.

For software troubleshooting a publishing platform, a PTO blackout during peak summer months was initiated without consulting lower level staff, and ended up being mostly unnecessary due to shifting timeline.

Healthcare has become more expensive in the past 3 years, and various other benefits have been axed with no intention on restoring them.

pros:
- Good benefits (in 2016-2018)
- Good location in Metro Center
cons:
- Dishonest about layoffs 
- lack of clarity on scope of job description
- Consolidation of several C suite roles into a single person creating significant power imbalance 
- Not diverse
- Majority of leadership was white upper class 
- Majority of staff isn't diverse
- No room for growth
- Old tech 
- Layoffs are bias to marginalized staff and management will say there are no upcoming layoffs and then lay people off. They take the people who will be laid off into an office to tell them they will be let go while they simultaneously hold a meeting with the other staff members announcing the lay off.
- High turnover in HR

pros: it's a great company! I like to work there.
cons: Not sure about it, I think everything goes well.

pros: Nice job to do for graduates
cons: Fun work. Great experience. High salary

pros: Worthy mission. Nice office and location. Dedicated staff. Family friendly, good work-life balance. The AAAS name still has meaning. You can keep your head down and do some good work.
cons:
Mediocre pay at best and no focus on staff development. This may be why there's such turnover.

Performance reviews are cursory and meaningless. You can put in extra effort and be effective, or you can coast, either way it doesn't seem to matter.

The pay increases were minimal even before COVID-19 and mostly not related to performance. From a job satisfaction standpoint, odds are your manager can't or won't spend too much time thinking about results and is in no position to reward you anyway.

Current CEO seems smart and caring but other senior staff don't seem particularly competent or able to lead or coordinate. This has been a problem across chief executives.

pros: Great benefits, flexible work schedule
cons: Provide a better annual increase

review_title: An Organization Unworthy of Its People
pros:
- Overall, AAAS is a community of kind-hearted, generous, and supportive individuals. You will always find help if you ask for it. There is a certain camaraderie AAAS staff share that you don't find everywhere. There are a few unsavory characters, but for the most part, people are good. Sadly, much of the bonding is over mistrust/dislike of leadership and their decisions.
- DEI training seems to be making a difference and is not completely performative (unlike the usual initiatives leadership undertakes that shoot for brownie points on a budget). I attended meetings with leaders who reframed objectives with DEI in mind, which was refreshing given earlier experiences at the org.
- It's probably a decent place to twilight your career (not looking for growth or a dynamic atmosphere).
- Current CEO's heart is in the right place.
- Work satisfaction is possible, though appears to vary from team to team (e.g., editorial/publishing vs programs)
cons:
In short, the org now has all the negatives of a non-profit and none of the positives. Frankly, the place reeks of late-stage capitalism. Everyone is expected to give it their all and be a "force for science" with little in the way of ROI.

Pay/Advancement
- Per other reviews, the pay is low and wages have stagnated. Especially at the lower levels, which is backwards for how the non-profit vs for-profit salary comparison generally works. Because AAAS is a non-profit, you can Google and find the org's tax returns and see how much the higher-ups are making. It'll boil your blood.
- Raises: even in years when inflation is not 6%, like 2021, the pooled "merit" increase has not kept pace with inflation. It ranged from 2.5%–3% during my tenure. ***This means you are taking an effective pay cut by staying with the company unless you are promoted, which rarely happens.*** The merit increase should be designated as a COL increase and given to all employees, with an additional increase based on performance. As it stands, there's no real reason to work hard here – you'll get the same as under-performers.
- Don't expect to use cutting-edge tech or learn competitive skills.

Benefits (a surprise given the other reviews, but hear me out)
- Health insurance: when I started at AAAS, my premium was $10/pay period with a low or no deductible (can't recall). When I left, the company had largely pushed everyone to a high deductible plan ($2k deductible), with a premium of $30+/pay period. The first year they rolled this plan out, they contributed $1k to employee HSAs, $500 the second. I'm guessing $250 or $0 next year. Worse yet was the org's denial of these increases. During the past two years' benefits enrollment presentations, HR has chirped "We're *so* excited to share with you these plans. They're really great plans, etc." You're speaking to a company of intelligent people, who can research and compare the offerings of peers at other orgs. Furthermore, to have the gall to say the plans are great when they're significantly worse than the prior year is insulting. Again, the hike in health care costs adds to the penalty in real wages employees suffer by staying at AAAS.
- Retirement: Yes, the retirement plan allows you to contribute 4%, which the company will match, and on top of that, they'll give 8%. However, when your salary is 20% below market average, this is negated. You'd be better off with a worse 401k but average pay elsewhere. Furthermore, while a 5-year, graduated vesting plan is not uncommon, the vesting used to be instant after 6 months. This change was very secretly rolled out and another instance of the company's willful acts to avoid transparency.
- Education: As an academia-adjacent org, AAAS places emphasis on having degrees, yet no longer (since ~2018) offers tuition assistance or repayment benefits, even if the degree is directly related to your position. Also, completion of a degree does not come with a raise. See: late-stage capitalism.
- PTO: For a non-profit in DC in 2021, the PTO is low. 12 days to start may have been something in the 80s, but when for-profits are offering 3wks or unlimited, it makes it hard to justify working for less money as well.

Siloing/Power Hoarding/Dynamics: You'll often find managers who are leery of employees communicating with other departments. Inefficiency runs rampant as a result of leaders refusing to let others perform certain tasks or work with other teams. Feelings and personal ties often get in the way of change that is needed. Productiveness is not rewarded on a team or individual level.

HR: At any org, HR's primary objective is to protect the company. Ideally, they at least try to find middle ground with the employees' interest. It's extra-despicable when this doesn't happen at a non-profit. Managers have gotten away with murder at AAAS, but since removing them would be an admission of guilt, HR has been slow to do so. Employee turnover is disastrous, and somehow it is lost on HR/the org that it is more costly to recruit and hire than it is to make the changes needed to keep employees. Being understaffed fuels more turnover as the remaining staff are overburdened, and the situation snowballs. Lastly, understaffing and internally politics keep people from moving where their skills might better be used/offer them chances of advancement.

pros:
Phenomenal mission and a true leader in advancing science to serve society.
Really good benefits and incredibly smart and passionate colleagues. The organization has always been a leader in diversity, equity, & inclusion in STEM; and has recently taken real action to become more inclusive as an organization.
cons: The senior leadership and board do not have a strong understanding of the importance and true impact of programmatic work. This leads to more of a corporate mindset where a community-engagement, non-profit framing would be more useful.

pros: AAAS has great benefits especially healthcare and sick leave
cons: Unfortunately, compensation isn’t the best.

job_title: Senior Project Director in Washington, DC
pros: With the addition of a new CEO committed to diversity, equity, and inclusion, some reorganization of leadership in the C-suite, and greatly increased transparency between leadership and staff, AAAS has made leaps and bounds in the last year and a half. There is still a long way to go, but the work is finally going in the right direction.
cons:
There is an assumption that staff opinions/input will make its way up to the top -- that doesn't usually happen, and with some left over mistrust of the leadership on the part of middle management and below, staff still do not feel their voices are always being heard.

Compensation is lower than usual within the DC area, but the benefits are absolutely incredible and tend to make up for the lower pay.

The path for professional growth is not always obvious.

pros: Good to see in the company
cons: Nothing is there to. Update

pros:

* Transparent and clear expectations regarding what you will be doing when hired
* Managers and HR show kindness and understanding all throughout the interview process
* Don't have to negotiate a salary (reduces anxiety for some)
* Great benefits + retirement package (even including pet insurance)
* Get to work around the top minds in the world, and the cutting edge of research
cons:
* Don't get to negotiate a salary (con for those who have extra experience)

review_title: A great experience, frustrating at times
job_title: Science and Technology Policy Fellow in Washington, DC
pros: If selected, you will get an opportunity to experience the policy and programmatic side of federal government from inside the Executive, Judicial, or Congressional branches of government and just maybe be able to effect some real change.
cons: The program caters to the government agencies and sometimes fellows are victims of personality problems. AAAS STPF will not (is not able to) support fellows who are denied security clearance or do not fit well in their offices in finding new positions. This means all of the risk is on the fellow- you move to DC, start working, and can have the rug pulled out from underneath you. This fellowship is not recommended for eccentric types.

pros: Vacation is good as is the retirement plan with a very nice building

Heavy workload

pros: Great benefits, great coworkers, interesting work

cons: Hard to be fired from this place which can be con when you have lazy & toxic staff. Need to stop hiring phd/academic folks in more business/ business operations oriented positions.

pros: Learn a lot. Great co-workers.

pros: Some wonderful colleagues and the opportunity to work on cool and rewarding projects.
cons: Full of silos and if your team has even one toxic person you're stuck. A lot of politics that can make it hard to get your job done even if you stay out of it.

pros: Nice good , experience well management

pros:

review_title: An organization that does great things despite some internal challenges
pros: AAAS employs many great people who care deeply about organization's mission. AAAS does high profile, impactful work in science policy, public engagement with science, and education in addition to producing the Science family of journals. I feel very proud of the work I've done as part of this organization.
cons: Internal communications, decision-making and organizational direction from leadership are often murky. Many 'silos' of expertise and activity contribute to inefficiency. Heavy turnover in staff in recent years has exacerbated a lot of problems. Internal opportunities for advancement are poor. Professional development opportunities within the organization are poor.

pros: The work that’s done is impactful and important. The support, even virtually, is 100 % tailored to the betterment of the employees. CEO Sudip is engaging and make us all proud to work for AAAS.
cons: AAAS is a non-profit, so pay will be lower than other places. While career growth is heavily encouraged by the Association, opportunities can vary based on your career path.

pros: Science magazine is well known.
cons: Managers are terrible. They seem to promote the least qualified people for these positions. Speaking of promotions, there is no way to advance here if you are qualified.

pros: Everyone on my team has been so helpful, welcoming, and friendly!
cons: How far out the first paycheck is, it can be an inconvenience.

pros: Colleagues very responsive, support from my manager, great CEO and excellent benefits
cons: I have not found any cons yet.

pros: AAAS is extremely diverse, mainly women, LGBTQ friendly, and minority friendly.

job_title: Customer Service Representative (CSR) in Fremont, CA
pros: great company to work for

review_title: Great Benefits, Terrible Management and HR
pros: At first blush, AAAS was a great place to work. The benefits are great, the workplace was quiet and clean, and the company does good work. CEO Rush Holt has a great vision. If you don't mind doing more or less the same thing every day, it will probably go very well for you.
cons: Management is completely and utterly inflexible. If you need accommodation for a disability, particularly an invisible disability, you're probably better off working somewhere else because they will not budge. They would rather get someone else than change anything, even if doing so would be very easy, because they are concerned about other employees asking for accommodations. HR is not your friend, and if they've decided they don't like you, they will push to get you fired. Additionally, AAAS really doesn't care about your career development. I spent months asking to go to various career development groups at AAAS and was routinely turned down by my supervisor. The resources are available. It's just that none of the lower level employees were allowed to access them.

review_title: Great experience, but company has reportedly changed
pros: When I worked at AAAS, the firm was a wonderful place to grow. I particularly liked that it was involved with a broad range of science, and many of the employees had a sincere commitment to the organization's goal of "advancing science and serving society." The company/AAAS brand also has a very strong reputation outside of its walls, particularly among other scientific nonprofits. When I worked there, I felt that I was working with some of the smartest people I've ever met, and probably ever would.
cons: I have heard that the company's mood and values have changed substantially since the time I was there. Particularly surprising is that I've heard that some long-time, knowledgeable and valuable employees have been unceremoniously dismissed, or walked away, in the past few years, owing to a significant restructuring effort. I remain friends with a number of people on the staff, and my sense is that they have found that the organization's efforts to restructure have left them feeling uncertain and vulnerable. I have also heard that there has recently been a change in the HR department that has put someone with surprisingly poor qualifications in charge.

pros: Good place for the Job
cons: Good place to a work

review_title: Use to be a great place to work but not anymore
pros: There are still many dedicated folks who are terrific at their jobs and truly care about the work and their direct reports. Very good benefits particularly the 403b.
cons:
Very political! The "peons" are not given the respect they deserve although they're the ones doing the hard work and implementing the projects. AAAS has begun to focus more on the membership which is great, but they hired these overbearing and entitled people to run that department...horrible folks! Condescending and pushy to a fault. 

The HR department has become a joke. It's now being run by the most unprofessional, petty, entitled, under-qualified person ever. If you get on their bad side watch out as they will do everything in their power to get you fired. Between HR and Membership it's like a Mean Girls reunion.

pros:
- Great mission with some really cool programs
- Benefits are amazing
- Location
- Organization is trying to get better
- Opportunities for growth 
- Gym
cons:
- Was shocked that such a prestigious organization could be this much of a mess internally
- Communication from the top down is terrible 
- High turnover due to really bad managers and outdated processes; okay there are a few good managers in the building
- No clear organizational vision or strategy; every department kind of fends for itself
- If you work in a support department it will be a rough transition coming here. The non-support staff (i.e. programs, publishing, editorial, etc.) have unrealistic expectations and will make you their personal admin or you will quit. Forget your expertise or experience because they want things done their way and immediately
- Lack of diversity at the senior management and director level

pros: The organization's mission is great, nice offices, great junior staff, benefits are outstanding.
cons: AAAS wants to be a big publisher but that is far from the truth.  Turnover seems rampant due to dysfunction in the sales and editorial groups and low salaries and no advancement opportunities.  The publisher has zero strategic direction and seems out of touch, letting a couple of his direct reports run the department. He recently promoted someone into a sales director role with no sales experience who treats some other staff disrespectfully and is very difficult to work with.  As a result of all this there are a lot of recent departures of well qualified staff and a diminishing brand in the marketplace.

review_title: Frustrating at times, rewarding at others
pros: I feel like I do good work here. Benefits are great, but the pay is only so-so.
cons:
- Little opportunity for advancement. Whenever a senior manager leaves, they seem to just expand the duties of another senior manager, which doesn't make room for anybody else to ever move.
- Management can't make decisions and won't listen to employees. Every decision is sent to a committee. Basic hiring decisions need to be run by the CEO. 
- Severely understaffed in some departments and overstaffed in others.

pros: Excellent colleagues and immediate managers and provides unique opportunity to contribute directly to science, writ large, and the good of society and the planet. Benefits are excellent. Flexibility, independence, and general respect are key factors that help to counter some of the significant negatives, however, these may not apply throughout the organization.
cons: Pay is extremely uncompetitive, being well below comparable positions (even at non-profits) both inside and outside of the region. There is little to no opportunity for advancement which results in many highly trained and qualified people feeling frustrated about opportunities to live up to their full potential. There has been some movement to try to rectify some of the internal issues, but it remains to be seen whether these efforts will amount to changes significant enough to address the erosion of employee satisfaction that is occurring.

review_title: Prestigious organization the produces high level science journals
pros: AAAS is a non-profit with a rich history both as a membership organization as well as a high level scientific publisher of peer-reviewed journals.  Historically employees could easily spend their entire careers at AAAS as they really cared about their employees.  The atmosphere was very stimulating and the employees work hard to deliver the highest possible journal content.
cons: The upper management has changed in the last several years and the dedication to employees has been lost.  They have terminated employees that have worked there for many years in favor of replacing them with employees with less experience.  Sadly, they have become less like a non-profit and more like an corporation that has no heart.

pros: Retirement benefits are better than anywhere else, CEO Holt is very personable, employees encouraged to be innovative, organization is trying to become better
cons: Organization does not have a policy for working remotely, so the ability to do so differs from department to department. interdepartmental collaboration and communication isn’t the best. Some employees have been there for decades and it is not known what they do or why they are still there despite mediocre performance. high turn over rate, probably due to some departments not respecting the expertise of other employees from other departments and insisting on things being done their way.

pros: Good mission and plenty of great people in the building
cons: While there are some very brilliant and good people in the building, depending on where you are you may be surrounded by very toxic people.  Good luck getting even the simplest tasks accomplished.  Senior managers are very territorial and the level of infighting does not bode well for the organization.  The level of turnover is very high, while I was there at least one person a day left or were forced to leave - across all levels.  HR is a joke.  They are incapable of getting even the simplest tasks done.  They make a lot of promises up front, but as soon as you are in the door, you are left to fend for yourself.  If you are fairly satisfied with your job, be wary about accepting an offer from AAAS.  You will probably end up regretting it.

pros: Very good benefits including a great retirement match, lots of sick time, and good location
cons:
I've worked in multiple departments but this has only confirmed my original feeling that everything AAAS does is outdated and in severe need of improvement. The teams even in the same department are extremely siloed and there are uncountable amounts of money being wasted on old unnecessary systems and different teams doing the same work (but not talking). 

I don't know how to turn this around as it has been this way the entire time I've been here with multiple managers. 

We're getting a new CEO soon so maybe there is some hope that we can finally make some changes

pros: Great modern office building and location in downtown Washington DC.  Most employees have their own office with a great view of chinatown or the old post office.  The location is only a block from metro center (metro station).  The majority of the staff members are friendly and easy to work with.  The company has great benefits: employee contribution 403(b) plan, 2 weeks paid vacation, holidays, and 2 extra holidays, flex plan, good health care options with low premiums, dental plan, transportation partially subsidized, and normaly a yearly bonus.  The staff is mostly older, which can be good and bad for an organization.  I would like to see some young staff be hired and get involved with the future of the organization.
cons: Career advancement is tough.  Not a lot of room to move around or up in the organization.

pros: The new CEO, Dr. Holt is truly working hard to eliminate silos. He also is incorporating all levels of employees to engage strategies and planning to increase memberships. Also, the environment at AAAS is extremely healthy, welcoming and everyone is very professional.
cons: H.R. isn't very efficient or effective in any manner what-so-ever. They often turn a blind eye as not to rock the boat. My manager told me they hadn't had a review in 10 years and it shows. There is no over site for management on any level so they tend to behave in a manner that reflects this lack of accountability.

pros: Great coworkers and friendly environment.  Competitive benefits package, with lots of vacation and sick days. Covers about 50% of your commute costs (if you use the metro). Encourages continuing training/education, but not equally across departments. Work from home is an option. Flexible hours and great location.
cons: The compensation is less than satisfactory, as this is a non-profit. You're expected to produce high quality product for less pay. There is also a disconnect between the higher management and its staff. Exhibits lack of understanding on issues important to the employees. Very low budget in areas where its most needed. Not all departments receive equal opportunity for employee training and continuing education. Some send their staff out to conferences regularly, whereas other departments are unable to make such an investment.

review_title: Too Large for Its Own Good
pros:
AAAS pulls off many remarkable projects with a generally dedicated and loyal staff. They have a great reputation, but also a heightened sense of what that means.

Awesome volunteer opportunities. HR team is great. Matching metro benefit is a huge plus.
cons:
The organization is too large and does not implement systems  that smaller nonprofits are able to pull off. There is no member database for all staff access and many platforms vary department to department. The overall policy and structure is lacking. This results in a fragmented organization. It's hard to navigate and know if teams are making similar efforts.

Some departments work well together, others don't - varies greatly. You are very siloed within the department you are hired for.

pros: Great mission. CEO and many executives have the right vision are committed to mission.
cons: Organization is in utter chaos.  During my time there, there were many exits at all levels.  Very disconcerting and sometimes it almost seemed like secret police took and disappeared people.  HR does not work very well.  Getting answers to basic questions like how much vacation will I accrue, can I carry over, clarification on handbook rules was like trying to get state secrets out of someone.  People are drawn in with big promises and fairly competitive pay and benefits but are not set up to succeed.  Depending on your department you may or may not get any training or guidance as far as expectations.  Job performance and expectations are very mercurial and are on the whims of your superior.

review_title: The Membership and IT departments are especially great
pros:
The work environment AAAS creates is amazing. Good work never goes unnoticed, and the organization has done a great job of hiring a knowledgeable and friendly staff. This was my first job out of college, and the work conditions were just a perfect fit for me. I was given instructions and encouraged to reach out for help, but allowed the freedom to figure tasks out for myself. 

My manager and colleagues welcomed and engaged me from day one of my employment as AAAS. They took my interests into account and made sure that I was given the opportunity to use the skills that I wanted to build.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: Good Benefits, but stuck in the 1980's, or maybe 1880's
pros:
-  Great Benefits; 401(k) employer contributions are unbeatable
-  Employer trust-  They hire smart, dedicated people, and trust them to do their work
cons:
-  incredibly silo'ed and political.  Internal departments view each other as rivals, not co-workers
-  Storied association, and they operate 30 years (at least) behind the times.  There is no agility here, every change takes years, and careful political calculation

review_title: Overall a decent place to work depending on your department
pros: Slowly but surely moving the right direction. Management was aware some growth and changes were needed, but did struggle to see how many of the challenges tied back to their leadership and communication to senior managers. Benefits were amazing. Some of the support staff were really great  people that helped to create a positive environment.
cons: I was on a team that developed some serious leadership problems, so that was the end of that.

review_title: Typical non-profit pay, atypical organization with a smart future
pros: Low stress, flexible vacation/personal time, great company outings, great coworkers, receptive management. Departmental cohesion means you are likely to make friends within days of joining AAAS. Casual Friday. Dedicated leaders.
cons: Non-profit pay, no bonuses, slightly understaffed, some communication issues. Due to the nature of the organization, almost everyone is on a tight deadline. The work hard (little play) mentality is strong in this organization. Although we have a roof-top lunch area, few people ever use it. Almost everyone chooses to eat at their desk.

pros:
Generous retirement plan, good location.
Interesting work
cons:
Organizational priorities are unclear. No consequences for poor performance
and no recognition of excellent performance. Departments that should work together are siloed. Some departments are put on a pedestal, making work for the rest of us more difficult. There is a lack of consistent standards and expectations. Advancement within is simply a waiting game, not due to merit.

SB: please do not leave a note on this review. We've already met and discussed.

pros: Science is a very well known journal and working for Science journals is a sought after opportunity.
cons: The place needs to move with the times. The management is older as are some of the long-time employees. The pay is sub-par and the promotion prospects are limited; younger employees end up moving on as a consequence. While the AAAS may be successful on a number of ventures, it does not value the work of editors who work at the Science family of journals. They seem apathetic to problems.

review_title: A non-profit mission with corporate leadership
pros:
-Exposure to a lot of interesting people and areas of science that keep the day-to-day work interesting

-Flexibility in my own position to try new things and come up with new ways to get my tasks done

-A lot of the staff who work on various programs are passionate and committed to their jobs

-Good benefits
cons:
-Senior leadership is fairly disrespectful to staff as a whole. As a result, many of us get our work done in spite of guidance from executives, not because of it. Executives will say one thing to appease you and then do the opposite behind your back

-Executives recognize that we need to modernize in a lot of ways, but a lot of initiatives don't work out because of poor planning and no transparency with the staff who will actually execute the initiatives

-There is a general sense that we're going in the wrong direction. The people who run the programs (the bread and butter of AAAS) don't have the ear of the executives like those in membership, publishing, etc. do. The result is that the programs are treated as an afterthought and it often feels like the executive team's main goal is to make money. This is a problem, because AAAS is a non-profit, not a corporation, so we have to balance our revenue-generating activities with the programs that we exist to provide to the public.

pros: Excellent opportunities to engage in the science policy community. Retirement contributions of employer are excellent. Up to a 4% contributions is matched by employer plus employer pays an additional 8%. So by saving 4% of your gross salary you end up saving 16%. Work environment is very pleasant. One of the best places I've ever worked in terms of friendly staff and people across the organization.
cons: Advancement seems slow. Raises have been 2% or 3% per year even with exceptional reviews. Paths for advancement are not clear.

pros: Mission-driven aspects of AAAS well-intentioned, many passionate, dedicated staff, meaningful mission and work. A lot of tenure across the organization.
cons: Think twice before accepting an offer with AAAS at this time. The things that have made the organization great are buried among cutthroat senior staff who are running AAAS into the ground. If you're not part of the "executive club" you have to watch your back. Preferential treatment clearly given to friends of HR and executive management. HR is unsafe and has a lot of turnover. Basically things across AAAS are in complete chaos.

review_title: Changing Organization with Lots of Opportunities
pros: Membership and Marketing are reinventing everything and having initial success in moving the organization toward a better approach.  Organization losing members over 10+ years and brought in new team to turn things around.  Benefits great, challenges if you like the reinventing and trying new approaches type of work environment.  Very can do attitude.  Staff committed to the mission.
cons: No merit based pay system. Somewhat bumpy with the amount of new people across the organization.  Some long-time employees change resistant.

review_title: Come for the Work Life Balance, Leave to Advance Your Career
pros:
* The work life balance is unbelievable. People do not work overtime unless absolutely necessary and it is easy to flex if you have to do something with your kids.
* The 401K matching is generous and immediate.
* Employee retention is off-the-charts. Some people have been here for FIVE decades!!!
cons:
* Not very much communication across programs and business units.
* It is a non-profit, so the pay is competitive but not spectacular.
* Needs to improve business processes.
* Relatively flat organization.

pros: AAAS has great employee benefits, especially their retirement plan.  The pay is competitive in the area compared to other non-profits.  The company allowed me opportunities to take additional training often.
cons: There is poor communication between senior management and middle management.  In my expereince I saw favoritism when it cam to promotions, raises and bonuses.

review_title: Ok for a little while but then...
pros: Starting out I actually liked working there. The office space was great, I felt some sense of privacy. The health benefits were pretty good as well.
cons: The pay was mediocre and there is tons of office politics which most likely will result in you becoming unemployed. Also, no matter what happens unless you're in a management role they will not take your concerns or complaints seriously. Lastly, growth was nearly impossible.

pros:
-Great benefits  
-Opportunity to take on challenging projects
-Ability to telecommute
-Company-wide events to meet with other coworkers
cons: They do not promote advancement within the company.  Accepted a higher position within the company and was scolded by HR for making the move because they thought I had a problem with my manager who they didn't like when I actually just wanted to advance my career and make more money without burning bridges.

review_title: Love the work, hate the office environment
pros: Excellent benefits package; prestigious organization; can feel good about your job; challenging and stimulating work.
cons: Favoritism from upper management (promotions not necessarily based on performance); not a lot of room for growth; can be a hostile work environment; no support from upper management, and not a motivating or morale-boosting environment.

review_title: Great learning experience and environment  for young professionals.
pros: Challenging and semi-fast paced work environment. With each successful project and/or display of maturity, a gradual increase of projects, responsibility and accountability is given in turn.
cons: Camaraderie among different departments is very divisive and individuals who are not keen on 'Type A' supervisors may want to do a thorough job during their interview process.

review_title: Need for investment, stability for employees
pros: Great mission, measurable success, good coworkers.
cons: We've had a lot of recent changes in leadership. Weak effort to reassure employees. They rely on hiring temps, don't address pay disparities. They provide no clear path for improvement or progress or raises. The work can be tedious. The employees are some of the biggest assets, but it doesn't seem like AAAS knows that.

pros: Great federal policy experience, invaluable networking opportunities in and around DC.
cons: If you need security clearance, you may have to wait a long time to get to work.

job_title: Science and Technology Policy Fellow in Chicago, IL
pros:
Offers the chance to exercise and build scientific skills in a federal agency and to work with top-tier agency scientists.
Excellent professional development and mentorship opportunities.
Competitive salary that takes your earnings history into account. Many placements include a health benefits package.
cons: The fellowship's professional development offerings are aimed more at early-career than mid-career scientists. However, I found it easy to work with my host office and other fellows to get what I wanted out of the program.

review_title: Greatest place on earth to work
pros: The benefits are outstanding, the building is beautiful, and you're working with people who really care about their mission.
cons: The DC metro is a steaming pile of fail. However when you get to the office look at the artwork for a few minutes, it can really center you. Yes, they have artwork.

review_title: What was good is turning bad like sour milk...
pros: Some of the people are wonderful.
cons: Lots of changes and firing of loyal employees has made HR a joke and jeopardized the mission of the organization. New hires in membership and marketing are atrocious individuals and have no clue what they are doing.

review_title: A company that tries but does not want to leave print behind.
pros: Very considerate HR staff.  AAAS/Science Magazine really tries to make woking comfortable and safe for all of its employees.  They provide very generous benefits and salaries.
cons: Not sure of their future direction.  They lost many of their top IT talent because they move too slowly with technology.

pros: Great mission and vision. You get to feel good about representing science.
cons: Senior managers use their authority like a weapon. Process is lorded over you like you are asking for a guilded office chair versus just trying to do your job. There are far more people that can tell you no, than there are that can help you figure the place out. HR is vindictive and abusive in their power over staff. No opportunity to defend yourself against HR.

pros: The mission of the organization is extremely important and meaningful
cons: No transparency regarding motivations and goals in executive office/leadership actions that directly impact staff,  total disconnect b/t leadership and staff, misaligned priorities in needed goal to align achieve sustainable financing.  Unbelievable salary disparity between staff and top executives in face of financial hard time.

review_title: Transformation of AAAS under the leadership of Rush Holt, CEO
job_title: Marketing and Membership Consultant in Vienna, VA
pros: AAAS staff is bright and committed to the mission of the association.
cons: Too many systems and silos that don't always communicate with others

pros: Great name in the industry, huge involvement with science community, very welcoming employees, great access to Rush Holt CEO
cons: Not a great company for young people, they don't do happy hours or internal events very often. Most people are comfortably mid-career and don't look to network very much externally or internally.

pros: Mission-driven, good work-life balance, people are passionate about what they're doing
cons: Departments are very siloed and have completely different policies on telework, no opportunities for advancement,  ongoing changes with senior leadership make it challenging to figure out where organization is headed

pros:
- A great association to work for
- Flexible hours
- Some very knowledgeable colleagues
- Good benefits and excellent 401k
cons:
- IT and Membership run the show
- Politics and favoritism
- Constant restructuring
- High turnover rate
- Lots of middle management 
- Meetings, meetings and more meetings

review_title: Working at AAAS Good and Not so Good
pros: Benefits are great, and lots of flexibility.
cons: No room for advancement, Top-heavy.  Zero confidentiality in HR.

pros: New technology .There is good learning. Atmosphere is is good. Work culture is good. You will be happy for what you are doing
cons: There is always scope of improvements. Because improvements will improve both the company and people. So we should go for improvements.

review_title: Good place to work although pay can be a bit better
pros: Great environment and benefits, fairly stable, people are really nice--the scientists and science nerds type.
cons: Pay a bit low, too much emphasis on equality, not enough reward for excellence.

job_title: Marketing Associate III in Washington, DC
pros: I worked in the office of publising and member services for over 5 years. Pros: Great People, Benefits, and opportunities to learn.
cons: Its a small nonprofit so the pay is a bit on the low end.

pros: The benefits are good and for the most part, so are the staff
cons: Senior management does not leave which makes it hard for growth and advancement opportunities

pros: Good benefits, smart people, mostly nice people.
cons: Very political, changing environment.  Certain departments are very male dominated.

pros: The pay is excellent, the benefits are incredible, the people in the organization are incredibly amazing, it's truly the best place to work.
cons: There are no cons, it's a great place.

pros: I learned a lot about scientific publishing and non-profit culture. The people are nice.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth and low pay.

review_title: On the way to great things.
pros:
-Lots of new initiatives hoping to retain talent.
-Great retirement benefits.
cons: -'Digital First' initiative promising but old guard still clings to old habits.

pros: The benefits and some staff
cons: Growth potential is minimal due to staff not retiring or resigning

pros: Great benefits, decent salary, quiet office environment
cons: Schedule isn't flexible, no telecommuting under normal circumstances

review_title: Good work environment, could pay more
pros: Good company culture, nice office, HR puts on events pretty frequently, good benefits
cons: Pay isn't particularly high, promotions aren't too frequent

pros: Very good benefits, location, and beautiful building. Great coworkers.
cons: Job growth can be a challenge.

pros: Wonderful mission and community to be a part of
cons: Large organization so sometimes different parts seem disconnected/I don't know as well.

pros: People, Work/Life Balance, Easy Commute, Benefits, 401k Match,
cons: Compensation is low even for non-profit technical band

pros: stable, strong benefits, great leadership by Sudip
cons: some processes are outdated, but they are aware and working towards fixing

pros: Positive work environment, continuous learning, flexibility, good management, work-life balance
cons: Can get hectic at times

pros: Good benefits, good people. Relaxed place with little micromanagement.
cons: Lack of communication between departments can cause some problems.

pros: Great benefits if salaries are a bit low
cons: bureaucracy, low salaries, slow innovation

pros: individual groups are passionate about what they do
cons: coordination across groups is poor

pros: Intelligent, long-standing and hardworking staff and company offers great benefis
cons: They could use more building space.

pros:
Nice working conditions 
nice people
cons:
no much growth
too stable not very exciting

pros: serves a good mission. good culture
cons: no movement up. HR is understaffed and underqualified

pros: benefits, flexible work hours, remote work
cons: silos, advancement ability is dependent on department

pros: Salary good Location Metro accessible
cons: I was fired after three days on the job with no reason only that i was an "AT Will Empolyeee" beware of this orgranzation and the HR dept is shady

pros: intelligent, motivated group of people
cons: no cons i can think of

pros: nice, flexible, fun, everyone is approachable
cons: none that I can think of

pros: Friendly staff, very helpful with new employees.
cons: None that I can think of.

pros: Interesting work; great network; flexible and friendly employer
cons: The salaries are relatively low

pros: Great people, always interesting work
cons: Low payment, not much internal communication

pros: working environment, management, performance bonus
cons: I don't think there are any

pros: good and comfortable work environment
cons: provide more opportunities for advancement

pros:
Benefits
Retirement
Office is nice, but a ton of open offices
cons:
Publishing lacks direction
Sales is run by customer service 
Culture of fear and back stabbing

pros: Very driven, self-motivated, and supportive staff.
cons: Senior management issues throughout organization.

pros: hard to say anything positive at this disappointing time
cons: toxic organizational culture, horrible treatment of employees, favoritism, boys club at the top

job_title: Member Services Associate in Washington, DC
pros:
-WMATA benefits
-Holidays off
-Close to metro
cons:
-Workload
-HR extremely unorganized
-Pay was low
-Management

pros: I have no pros to add.
cons: HR and membership department are a joke
